msItem.title: capitula
msItem.rubric: Ad laudem et gloriam domini nostri Iesu Christi ac perpetue gloriose uirginis Marie matris eius inceptus et scriptus est liber iste qui intitulatur Speculum humane uite anno Domini millesimo cccc. quadragesimo sexto ad utilitatem legencium uidelicet incipiencium, proficiencium et perfectorum, qui quidem liber diuiditur in quinque partes in quarum principio docetur per capitula quid in eis continetur
msItem.note: (The capitula of bk. 1 are repeated at the end).

msItem.incipit: Fili ait scriptura accedens ad seruitutem Dei
msItem.explicit: et in itinere securitas et in peruencione felicitas, prestante Domino nostro ... .
msItem.finalRubric: Et sic finitur totus liber qui dicitur Speculum uite humane scriptus atque completus per manum domini Iohannis Gisburgh capellani penultimo die Ianuarii anno Domini millesimo quadringentesimo quadragesimo nono.
msItem.note: Incorporates ADAM THE CARTHUSIAN, Speculum Spiritualium, bks 2–6: pr. Paris 1510; Bloomfield 5934; Allen, Richard Rolle, pp. 405–6; Sharpe, Handlist, pp. 8–9.

msItem.author: JAMES OF MILAN (Ps.-BONAVENTURE)
msItem.title: Stimulus Amoris
msItem.incipit: (c. 1) Primo studeat quisque quantum potest se uilissimum reputare et indignum omni beneficio Dei
msItem.explicit: (c. 21) debes tamen plus orare pro illis quibus magis es obligatus. Explicit.
msItem.note: Ed. Bibl. Francisc. Ascetica Medii Aevi 4 (Quaracchi, 1949), pp. 6–122, but this version varies much from the printed text; Bloomfield 4159.

msItem.title: Sermo
msItem.rubric: Ammonicio beati Augustini ad populum suum.
msItem.incipit: Rogo uos f. k. quociens ad ecclesiam Dei conuerteris longe a uobis deicite ociosos sermones
msItem.explicit: in eterna conuiuia cum suis dilectis qui ...
msItem.finalRubric: Excerpta ammonicio Augustini ad populum suum.
msItem.note: An adaptation of Caesarius, Serm. 80, common in English MSS; another seven copies are in Römer 1. 383.

msItem.author: Ps.-AUGUSTINE
msItem.title: Liber Meditationum 1–9
msItem.incipit: Quedam deuota meditacio beati Augustini ad Patrem et Filium et Spiritum Sanctum. Domine Deus meus da cordi meo te desiderare
msItem.explicit: secundum multitudinem tuarum complaceat miseracionum per ...
msItem.note: PL 40. 901–9. The copy in CUL Dd. 1. 21 (s. xiv) ends at the same point.

msItem.title: Narrationes
msItem.rubric: Incipiunt declamaciones Senece cum suis moralibus liber primus.
msItem.incipit: Prima declamacio de Christo et mundo uel de anima et corpore narrat Seneca libro primo declamacione prima
msItem.note:
Followed by three notes: ‘De anima peccatrice’, ‘De continua meditatione Christi’, and ‘Nota de cane natante per aquam cum osse quod ore portauit uidens umbram ossis in aqua aperuit os suum ad capiendum umbram sic amisit utrumque. Versus Os canis ore gerit umbram uidit irrita querit
Irritus os aperit os cadit umbra perit. Explicit.’

msItem.title: Ars bene Moriendi

msItem.incipit: (fols. 200–6) Cum de presentis exilii miseria mortis transitus propter moriendi inpericiam
msItem.explicit: ut in pace sit locus et habitacio tua in Ierusalem celesti per eundem Dominum ...

msItem.rubric: Item incipit alia doctrina siue exemplum de morituris.
msItem.incipit: Fuit quidem papa qui dum ad extrema uenisset interrogabat capellanum suum uirum ydoneum et deuotum .... Salua animam eius in hac hora exitus sui aperi ei ianuam uite et fac eam gaudere cum sanctis tuis in gloria .... Domine Iesu Christe qui redemisti nos precioso sanguine tuo scribe in anima huius famuli tui
msItem.explicit: mors occupet mori discat. Ecce conclusio omnium prescriptorum.

msItem.note: Pr. Naples 1476 (GW 592), &c.; Bloomfield 1076, many copies; on the authorship, M. C. O’Connor, The Art of Dying Well (New York, 1942), pp. 48–60.

msItem.title: Meditacio mortis
msItem.incipit: Mors est eterna sompnus dissolucio corporis
msItem.explicit: ad glorificandum omnes electos cum quibus nobis glorificari concedat qui sine fine uiuit et regnat amen.

msItem.author: HENRY SUSO
msItem.title: Horologium Diuinae Sapientiae II. 2
msItem.rubric: Incipit scientia utilissima hominum que est scire mori et qualiter moriendum sit.
msItem.incipit: Scire autem mori est paratum habere cor
msItem.explicit: ad locum immortalitatis et filicitatis eterne amen.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit extractio medullita libri autentici qui uocatur orilogium diuine sapientie.
msItem.note: Ed. P. Künzle, Heinrich Seuses Horologium sapientiae, Spicilegium Friburgense 23 (1977), pp. 527 line 15–540 line 11; Bloomfield 5416; Kaeppeli 1852.

msItem.author: Richard de Castre
msItem.title: Prayer to Jesus
msItem.rubric: Oracio magistri Ricardi Castre quam ipse composuit.
msItem.explicit: and spare me yt I be noȝt spilt.
msItem.note: Lines 1–32, ed. J. Furnivall, EETS o.s. 24 (1867), 15–16; C. Brown, Religious Lyrics of the Fifteenth Century (Oxford, 1939), no. 64 and p. 313; IMEV 1727.

msItem.title: Psalterium caritatis fraterne
msItem.incipit: Jesu for hem I ye beseche
msItem.explicit: And spare hem yt ȝei have don amys. Explicit.
msItem.note: Part of art. 10, beg. as the copies in Longleat 30, fol. 20, and Huntington Libr., HM 142, fol. 16v. Followed by two paragraphs: 'There was a woman called Veronica which metyng wt our lord goyng toward his passion and swetyng for grete anguysse delyuered him a clothe to clense his face wherin after he had wyped hym remayned the verrey figure of his face which is called the vernycle wher aftir this figure is made’, and ‘Ther beth girdils of saint Rose, which lith hole to this day at Vitarbe and enport special remedy both for wemen laboryng in childe and also agenst the feueres if yᵉ pacient be girde wt oon of hem. J. Gisburgh.’ IMEP, p. 52.
fols. 211v, 212v blank. On fol. 212 is a short note and an early table of contents.

supportDesc.collation: A singleton, 1–268, 274(lacks 3–4), a singleton; catchwords framed in red.

layoutDesc.layout: Frame-ruled with pencil in 2 cols; written in c. 50–5 lines.

handDesc.handNote: Begun in 1446 and completed on 30 Jan. 1449 by John Gisburgh, who writes a proficient bastard secretary hand.

decoDesc.decoNote: Large red and blue initials flourished and with partial borders in both colours; large blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs, red highlighting and underlining. Red running heads with blue paraphs.

binding.p: Standard Merton, s. xvii; sewn on seven bands; formerly chained from the usual position. fol. i is a paper binding-leaf from the same printed book as in MS 19. Fols. 1 and 212 were formerly pastedowns in an earlier binding. At the foredge of fol. 1, near the foot, is the mark of a brass chain-staple.

history.provenance: Made in England; it is not known when it entered the College prior to s. xvii.
Inside the front board is a table of contents and ‘G. 2, 3’ (canc.), s. xvii, and ‘P. 1. 1. Art:’, canc. and replaced with ‘N. 2. 1 (CCIV)’ in red; the College bookplate.
